metadata.title: Evolutionary arms race between virus and host drives genetic 1 diversity in bat SARS related coronavirus spike genes Science and Technology for Medicine of the Ministry of Education, College of Life Running title: Arms race between SARSr-CoVs spike gene and host

abstract.text: The Chinese horseshoe bat (Rhinolophus sinicus), reservoir host of severe acute 24 respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), carries many bat SARS-related CoVs 25 (SARSr-CoVs) with high genetic diversity, particularly in the spike gene. Despite 26 these variations, some bat SARSr-CoVs can utilize the orthologs of human 27 SARS-CoV receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), for entry. It is 28 speculated that the interaction between bat ACE2 and SARSr-CoV spike proteins 29 drives diversity. Here, we have identified a series of R. sinicus ACE2 variants with 30 some polymorphic sites involved in the interaction with the SARS-CoV spike protein. 31 Pseudoviruses or SARSr-CoVs carrying different spike proteins showed different 32 infection efficiency in cells transiently expressing bat ACE2 variants. Consistent
33 results were observed by binding affinity assays between SARS-and SARSr-CoV 34 spike proteins and receptor molecules from bats and humans. All tested bat 35

SARSr-CoV spike proteins had a higher binding affinity to human ACE2 than to bat 36 ACE2, although they showed a 10-fold lower binding affinity to human ACE2 37 compared with their SARS-CoV counterpart. Structure modeling revealed that the 38 difference in binding affinity between spike and ACE2 might be caused by the 39 alteration of some key residues in the interface of these two molecules. Molecular 40 evolution analysis indicates that these residues were under strong positive selection. 41 These results suggest that the SARSr-CoV spike protein and R. sinicus ACE2 may 42 have coevolved over time and experienced selection pressure from each other, 43 3 triggering the evolutionary arms race dynamics. It further proves that R. sinicus is the 44 natural host of SARSr-CoVs. 45 46 4 Importance 47 Evolutionary arms race dynamics shape the diversity of viruses and their receptors. 48 Identification of key residues which are involved in interspecies transmission is 49 important to predict potential pathogen spillover from wildlife to humans. Previously, 50 we have identified genetically diverse SARSr-CoV in Chinese horseshoe bats. Here, 51 we show the highly polymorphic ACE2 in Chinese horseshoe bat populations. These 52 ACE2 variants support SARS-and SARSr-CoV infection but with different binding 53 affinity to different spike proteins. The higher binding affinity of SARSr-CoV spike to 54 human ACE2 suggests that these viruses have the capacity of spillover to humans. 55 The positive selection of residues at the interface between ACE2 and SARSr-CoV 56 spike protein suggests a long-term and ongoing coevolutionary dynamics between 57 them. Continued surveillance of this group of viruses in bats is necessary for the 58 prevention of the next SARS-like disease. 59 60 5 Introduction 61 Coronaviruses belong to the Orthocoronavirinae subfamily and Coronaviridae 62 family. They are enveloped viruses and contain a positive-sense and single-stranded 63 RNA genome. There are four genera in this subfamily, Alphacoronavirus, 64 Betacoronavirus, Gammacoronavirus, and Deltacoronavirus. Alphacoronavirus and 65 Betacoronavirus are believed to have originated in bats or rodents while 66 Gammacoronavirus and Deltacoronavirus in birds (1, 2). Since the beginning of the 67 21 st century, three betacoronaviruses have caused outbreaks of severe pneumonia in 68 humans. These are, the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) 69 (3-5), the Middle-East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) (6) and the 70 ongoing 2019 novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) (7). 71 The SARS-CoV-2 outbreak has brought back memories of SARS-CoV that 72 occurred 17 years ago in China. SARS is a zoonosis, as demonstrated by the 73 identification of an almost identical coronavirus present in market civets in 74 Guangdong province, China (8). In the following years, genetically diverse 75 SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoV) were detected or isolated from horseshoe 76 bats from different regions of China and Europe (9-18). Bat SARSr-CoVs share 78-77 96% nucleotide sequence identity with human and civet SARS-CoVs, with the most 78 variable regions encoding the spike protein (S) and accessory protein ORF3 and 8 (17, 79 19). Moreover, we have identified all the building blocks of SARS-CoV in the 80 genome of different bat SARSr-CoVs and suggest that the ancestor of SARS-CoV 81 originated in bats through the recombination of bat SARSr-CoV genomes (17, 19).

body_text.text: The first and essential step of virus infection is cell receptor recognition. The entry 83 of the coronavirus is mediated by specific interactions between the viral S protein and 84 cell surface receptor, followed by fusion between the viral and host membrane. The 85 coronavirus S protein is functionally divided into two subunits, a cell attachment 86 subunit (S1) and a membrane-fusion subunit (S2). The S1 region contains an 87 N-terminal domain (NTD) and a C-terminal domain (CTD); both can be used for 88 coronavirus receptor binding (RBD) (20) . For SARS-CoV, its S1-CTD serves as an 89 RBD for binding to the cellular receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) 90 (21). Biochemical and crystal structure analyses have identified a few key residues in 91 the interface between the SARS-CoV S-RBD and human ACE2 (21-23). have a smaller S protein, due to 5, 12, or 13 amino acid deletions (17, 19) . Despite the 96 variations in the RBD, all clade 1 strains can use ACE2 for cell entry, whereas clade 2 97 strains, with deletions cannot (14, 16, 17) . These results suggest that members of 98 clade 1 are likely to be the direct source of SARS-CoV in terms of genome similarity 99 and ACE2 usage. Samples from three provinces (Hubei, Guangdong, and Yunnan) were used for 123 ACE2 amplification, based on the prevalence of bat SARSr-CoVs and tissue sample 124 availability and quality. In addition to previously sequenced bat ACE2 by our group 125 (sample ID 832, 411, and 3357, collected from Hubei, Guangxi, and Yunnan, 126 8 respectively) and others (GenBank accession no. ACT66275; sample collected from 127 Hong Kong), we obtained ACE2 gene sequences from 21 R. sinicus bat individuals: 128 five from Hubei, nine from Guangdong, and seven from Yunnan. The ACE2 129 sequences exhibited 98-100% amino acid (aa) identity within their species and 80-81% 130 aa identity with human ACE2 (Table S1 ). Major variations were observed at the 131 N-terminal region, including in some residues which were previously identified to be 132 in contact with SARS-CoV S-RBD ( Fig. 1A and Fig. S1 ). Analysis based on 133 nonsynonymous SNPs helped identify eight residues, including 24, 27, 31, 34, 35, 38, 134 41, and 42. The combination of these 8 residues produced eight alleles, including 135 RIESEDYK, LIEFENYQ, RTESENYQ, RIKSEDYQ, QIKSEDYQ, RMTSEDYQ, 136 EMKTKDHQ, and EIKTKDHQ, named allele 1-8, respectively (Fig. 1A) . In 137 addition to the ACE2 genotype data from previous studies (allele 4, 7, and 8), five 138 novel alleles were identified in the R. sinicus populations in this study. Alleles 2 and 4 139 were found in two and three provinces, respectively, whereas the other alleles seemed 140 to be geographically restricted. In summary, three alleles (4, 6, and 8) were found in 141 Guangdong, four (1, 2, 4, and 7) in Yunnan, three (2, 4, and 5) in Hubei, and one each 142 in Guangxi and Hong Kong. Coexistence of four alleles was found in the same bat 143 cave of Yunnan where the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV was found (Fig. 1B) . Taken 144 together, these data suggest that ACE2 variants have been circulating within the R. Similar to our previous report, all four bat SARSr-CoV strains with the same 176 genomic background but different S proteins could use human ACE2 and replicate at 177 similar levels (17). However, there are some differences in how they utilize R. sinicus 178 ACE2s ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S2 ). All test viruses could efficiently use allele 1, 2, 4, 5 for 179 entry. RsWIV1 and RsWIV16, which share an identical RBD, could not use allele 6 180 (sample ID 1434) from Guangdong. Rs4231 and RsSHC014, which share an identical 181 RBD, could not use allele 7 (sample ID 3357) and 8 (sample ID 1438) from Yu nnan 182 and Guangdong, respectively. SARS-CoV-BJ01, which shares high similarity with 183 WIV1 and WIV16 RBD, was able to use same bat ACE2 alleles as Rs4231 and 184 11 RsSHC014 in the pseudotyped infection assay ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S3 ). These results 185 indicate that cell entry was affected by both spike RBD and R. sinicus ACE2 variants. 1434ACE2 (allele 6) was found to bind RsSHC014 and BJ01 but not RsWIV1 RBD; 207 3357ACE2 (allele 7) was found to bind RsWIV1 but not RsSHC014 and BJ01 RBD; 208 5720ACE2 (allele 2) was found to bind all tested RBDs. All tested RBDs had a high 209 binding affinity to human or bat ACE2. BJ01 RBD had a higher binding affinity for 210 human ACE2 than did RsWIV1 and RsSHC014 RBDs (Fig. 3A , E, and I); however, 211 it had a lower binding affinity to bat ACE2 than the two bat SARSr-CoV RBDs ( The four tested spike proteins of bat SARSr-CoV are identical in size and share 227 over 90% aa identity with SARS-CoV, which suggests that these proteins have a 228 similar structure. In this study, we built structural complex models of bat 229 SARSr-CoV-RsWIV1 RBD with R. sinicus ACE2 3357 (allele 7) and RsSHC014 230 RBD with R. sinicus ACE2 1434 (allele 6), in concordance with the results of the 231 binding affinity assay between SARS-CoV RBD and human ACE2 (Fig. 4) . 232 Compared with the contact residues in the interface between SARS-CoV RBD and In R. sinicus ACE2-1434, we found a threonine at 31, unlike human ACE2, which 247 has a lysine at this position (Fig. 4) . Therefore, both RsWIV1 and RsSHC014 RBD had a lower binding affinity 268 to human ACE2 than did BJ01, but they both showed a higher binding affinity with Table 1) , 17 of 298 those were found to be located on the RBD region, which faces its receptor ACE2, 299 according to the crystal structure (Fig. S5) . Moreover, five of those (442, 472, 479, 300 480, and 487), present in the SARS-CoV spike, have been previously identified to 301 have a significant impact on binding affinity to human ACE2 (Fig. 4 (24, 27, 31, 34, 35, 38, 41, and 42) correspond to 306 the residues in human ACE2, which were previously identified to be involved in 307 18 direct contact with the human SARS-CoV spike protein (Fig. 4, Fig. S5 ) (32). We also 308 analyzed the ACE2 gene of Rhinolophus affinis (R. affinis), which has been reported 309 to carry SARSr-CoV occasionally (15). Used an alignment of 23 ACE2 gene 310 sequences from R. affinis obtained in this study, we found that R. affinis ACE2 was 311 more conserved between different individuals in the entire coding region than R. 312 sinicus ACE2 (Fig. S6) and no obvious positive selection sites were observed (data
Genes with important functions usually display a dN/dS ratio of less than 1 353 (negative selection) because most amino acid alterations in a protein are deleterious.

In a host-virus arms race situation, the genes involved tend to display dN/dS ratios Codon-based analysis of molecular evolution 536 Bat ACE2 and SARSr-CoV spike sequences were analyzed for positive selection. In 537 this study, bat ACE2 sequences were either amplified or downloaded from NCBI and 538 SARSr-CoV spike sequences were downloaded from NCBI; the database accession 539 numbers are listed in Table S2 . Sequences were aligned in Clustal X. Phylogenetic Table S2 .

FIGREF0.text: SARSr-CoVs, detected inRhinolophus sinicus, can be divided into two distinct 93 clades based on the size of the S protein. Clade 1 includes viruses that have S proteins 94 identical in size to the SARS-CoV S protein, whereas viruses belonging to clade 2 95

FIGREF1.text: 100ACE2 is functionally divided into two domains-the N-terminal domain is101 involved in SARS-CoV binding and the C-terminal domain in the regulation of heart 102 function (21, 24). Previous results have indicated that the C-terminal domains of 103 ACE2 from different origins are relatively well conserved, whereas the N-terminal 104 7 domains show much more diversity across species (25). Previously, we have shown 105 that SARS-CoV can utilize ACE2 derived from Myotis daubentonii and R. sinicus; 106 minor mutations in the RBD-binding site could convert ACE2 from being 107 unsusceptible to susceptible to SARS-CoV binding (26, 27). As all bat SARSr-CoV 108 belonging to clade 1 can utilize ACE2 and have been isolated from R. sinicus, we 109 asked whether variations in ACE2 of R. sinicus could contribute to the diversity of bat 110 SARSr-CoV. 111 Here, we have investigated the polymorphism of R. sinicus ACE2 genes and 112 assessed their susceptibility and binding affinity to different bat SARSr-CoV spike 113 proteins through a combination of molecular evolution analyses, protein affinity 114 assays, and virus infection assays. Our results showed that the diversity of the 115 SARSr-CoV spike protein may experience natural selection pressure from the R. 116 sinicus ACE2 variants; over long periods of co-existence, the SARSr-CoV spike 117 protein may be selected by R. sinicus ACE2 to maintain genetic diversity and to fit 118 with the population of R. sinicus. show high polymorphism among the R. sinicus populations 122

FIGREF2.text: 145 sinicus populations in different regions for a long time; substitutions at the sites 146 directly in contact with SARS-CoV S-RBD suggest that they may have important 147 functions during SARS-CoV evolution and transmission. 9 Phylogenetic tree of R. sinicus ACE2. 150 (A) The maximum-likelihood tree (left panel) was produced using MEGA6 software, 151 based on the alignment of ACE2 amino acid sequences of R. sinicus with the 152 Jones-Taylor-Thornton (JTT+G+I) model and bootstrap value (%) of 1000 replicates 153 (28). The eight key residues which are involved in interacting with the SARS-CoV 154 spike are indicated in the panel on the right. The eight residues of human ACE2 are 155 indicated at the bottom. The numbers at the top are amino acid positions in ACE2. (B) 156 Frequencies of ACE2 alleles among the R. sinicus population. The number of R. 157 sinicus ACE2 sequences is shown in the center of the pie chart. Different colored 158 sectors with percentages in the pie chart indicate allele frequencies of ACE2 in the R. 159 sinicus population used in this study. The alignments of complete amino acid 160 sequences of R. sinicus ACE2 are shown in supplementary Fig. S1. ACE2 sequences 161 of Rs-411, 832, and 3357 and Rs-ACT66275.1 have been published previously and 162 were downloaded from GenBank. The accession number of R. sinicus ACE2 163 10 sequences obtained in this study are listed in Table S2 164 165 R. sinicus ACE2 variants show different susceptibility to SARSr-CoV infection 166 To assess if different R. sinicus ACE2 molecules affect the entry of SARS-CoV and 167 bat SARSr-CoV, R. sinicus ACE2 variants were transiently expressed in HeLa cells 168 and the entry efficiency of SARS-CoV pseudotyped or bat SARSr-CoVs carrying 169 different S proteins were tested. The four tested bat SARSr-CoV strains can be 170 divided into four genotypes according to their S1 sequences, as reported previously 171 (17). Briefly, compared with SARS-CoV S protein, SARSr-CoV-RsWIV1 shares high 172 aa identity at the RBD; RsWIV16 is the closest relative of SARS-CoV and shows 173 high aa identity at both the NTD and RBD; Rs4231 shares high aa identity at the NTD; 174 and RsSHC014 shows divergence at both the NTD and RBD regions.

FIGREF9.text: 233 human ACE2, changes in or near the two virus-binding hotspots on ACE2 (hotspots 234 Lys31 and Lys353 consist of a salt bridge with Glu35 and Asp38, respectively) were 235 observed. As reported previously, the two hot spots are buried in a hydrophobic 236 environment. They provide a substantial amount of energy to the virus-receptor 237 binding interactions as well as fill critical voids in the hydrophobic stacking 238 interactions at the binding interface (21, 29).239Compared with human ACE2(Fig. 4A, C, D), R. sinicus ACE2-3357 contains 240 two main residue changes, E35K and Y41H. The E35K breaks the salt bridge with 241 K31 and Arg479 in RsSHC014 RBD, which may influence the binding affinity 242 between them. A histidine at position 41 may weaken the support for the K353-D38 243 salt bridge because it is a weaker hydrophobic stacker than tyrosine, resulting in 244 decreased binding affinity with BJ01 RBD (30). Consequently, BJ01 and RsSHC014 245 RBD showed a lower binding affinity with R. sinicus ACE2-3357.

FIGREF11.text: In addition, all R. sinicus ACE2s in this study contain an asparagine at position255 82 rather than a methionine in human ACE2. The M82N change introduces an 256 unfavorable hydrophilic residue which would weaken the hydrophobic network 257 around hot spot 31. Moreover, Asn82 introduces a glycosylation site, like that in rat 258 ACE2, which cannot support SARS-CoV infection efficiently; the glycan at position 259 82 of ACE2 may lead to steric interference with viral RBD binding. Hence, M82N 260 may have significant effects on the interaction between SARS-CoV and SARSr-CoV 261 RBD with R. sinicus ACE2s. As previously described, residue 487 of the RBD 262 interacts with hot spot 353 on ACE2. RsWIV1 contains an Asn487 in its RBD, the 263 polar side chain of Asn487 may have unfavorable interactions with the aliphatic 264 portion of residue Lys353 in ACE2, which may affect the hot spot interaction between 265 K353 and D38. Moreover, the RsSHC014 RBD contains an alanine at position 487; 266 the small side chain of Ala 487 does not provide support to the structure of hot spot 267 353 (19)

FIGREF12.text: Structure modeling at the interface between SARSr-CoV spike and 273 human or bat ACE2. 274 Detailed view of the interaction between RBD and ACE2. Several important residues 275 in RBD and ACE2 that are involved in the interactions are shown. ACE2 residues are 276 in green and RBD residues are in magenta. (A) List of eight contact residues in ACE2 277 from human and R. sinicus that are directly involved in RBM/ACE2 binding. (B) 278 Alignment of five residues from SARS-CoV and two SARSr-CoVs RBD that are 279 critical for receptor binding. (C) Structure complex of the SARS-CoV hTor2 RBD and 280 human ACE2 (protein data code 2AJF). (D) Predicted structure complex of R. sinicus 281 ACE2 3357 with RsWIV1 RBD. (E) Predicted structure complex of R. sinicus ACE2 282 1434 with RsSHC014 RBD. The model for RsWIV1 RBD and ACE2 was built based 283 on the structure of hTor2 RBD with hACE2 (protein data code 2AJF). The model for 284 RsSHC014 RBD and ACE2 was built based on the structure of civet-optimized RBD CoV spike genes have coevolved with R. sinicus ACE2 through positive 289 selection 290 To test the possible selection pressure acting on the SARSr-CoV spike and R. 291 sinicus ACE2 gene, we used the codeml program of the PAML software package (31) 292 to analyze the ratio of nonsynonymous to synonymous mutations (dN/dS ratios) at 293 individual codons. We analyzed the complete gene encoding the SARSr-CoV spike 294 protein by aligning nine SARSr-CoV spike gene sequences from R. sinicus samples. 295 We found that the models allowed codons to evolve under positive selection (M2a and 296 M8). In model M8 (initial seed value for ω (dN/dS) = 1.6, codon frequency = F3X4), 297 20 codons (p>0.95) were under positive selection with dN/dS>1 (

FIGREF13.text: 313 not shown). Additionally, by querying single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) 314 databases, we found that SNPs in human ACE2 gene arose randomly through the 315 entire coding region (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/snp/). Although we identified two 316 SNP sites with nonsynonymous mutation (T27A and E35K) in human ACE2, both 317 displayed a rare frequency in the global population (frequency 0.00001 and 0.00002, 318 respectively). These results indicate that positive selection has happened at the 319 interface between bat SARSr-CoV spike protein and R. sinicus ACE2.

FIGREF16.text: Twice the difference in the natural logs of the likelihoods (ΔlnL x 2) of the two models being compared. This value is used in a 328 likelihood ratio test along with the degrees of freedom. In all cases (M1a vs M2a), (M7 vs M8), (M8a vs M8), a model that 329 allows positive selection is compared to a null model. The p-value indicates the confidence with which the null model can be 330 rejected.

FIGREF17.text: , dN/dS value of the class of codons evolving under positive selection in model M8, and the percent of codons falling in that 332 class 333 e, Residues corresponding to codons assigned to the dN/dS>1 class in model M8 (p>0.95 by BEB). bats are widely distributed in China and carry genetically diverse 337 SARSr-CoVs. Two different clades of bat SARSr-CoVs were discovered, based on the 338 size and similarity of S protein to that of human SARS-CoV. SARSr-CoVs of clade-1, 339 only found in Yunnan province, have an S protein identical in size to SARS-CoV and 340 use the ACE2 receptor, whereas SARSr-CoVs of clade-2 are widely distributed in 341 China and cannot use ACE2 as the receptor (19). In this study, we analyzed ACE2 342 sequences of R. sinicus, collected from four provinces and one city, and observed 343 highly polymorphic sites, which correspond to those that interact with SARS-CoV 344 RBD, at the N-terminal region. Despite these variations, most ACE2s supported the 345 viral entry of clade-1 bat SARSr-CoVs, but with different susceptibilities and binding 346 affinities. In addition, we have identified key residues involved in the interaction 347 between the bat ACE2 variants and SARSr-CoV RBD by structural modeling and 348 positive selection analysis. These results indicate that SARSr-CoV has co-evolved 349 with its natural host, R. sinicus, for a very long time. Members of clade-1 use ACE2 350 as the receptor, whereas members of clade-2 exploit different receptor(s), due to the 351 deletions in S protein.

FIGREF18.text: greater than 1 (positive selection), specifically in the codons involved in the 356 interaction interface between the virus and its host, with minimal effect on their357 21 physical function (20, 33). In this study, our analysis of the SARSr-CoV spike protein 358 and R. sinicus ACE2 gene sequences showed that some codons related to the 359 interaction interface between them were under positive selection. Similar rapid 360 adaptation for SARS-CoV occurred during the SARS outbreak in 2002-2003 (21, 34). 361 When SARS-CoV was transmitted from market civet to human, the spike gene 362 experienced positive selection, where mutations in two critical residues (amino acids 363 479 and 487) of the spike protein changed the binding affinity of the virus to human 364 ACE2 from low to high; subsequently, turning into a pandemic strain (34). 365 An increasing number of studies have suggested that co-evolution is driven by 366 specific interactions between high levels of virus sequence divergence and 367 polymorphic host receptors (20, 33, 35-38). The first example was observed for the 368 avian leucosis virus infection in which receptor polymorphism in chicken could alter 369 the sensitivity to virus entry (36). Arms race can also occur between the glycoproteins 370 of two different viruses, as seen for the rodent arenavirus and the mouse mammary 371 tumor virus, with their receptor transferrin receptor 1 (TfR1) (39). 372 In a continuous coevolutionary process, viruses often tend to decrease their 373 virulence to fit both the host and the virus population. The "trade-off hypothesis" is 374 the most popular explanation for why pathogens often do not reach their maximum 375 reproductive potential (40, 41

FIGREF19.text: passages in vitro. Furthermore, mutations detected in the RBD of MERS-CoV spike 388 protein enhanced viral entry and replication on cells expressing drDPP4 within three 389 passages (49). Similarly, adaptive mutations have occurred in the Ebola virus 390 envelope protein, which contacts its receptor, NPC intracellular cholesterol transporter 391 1, when it crossed the host-virus barriers, was transmitted to different hosts, and 392 entered the human population (50-53). These examples are a warning that the 393 SARSr-CoVs circulating in R. sinicus may adapt to other animal hosts, including 394 humans, and cause the next SARS-like disease. Therefore, it is important to 395 continually monitor SARSr-CoVs in R. sinicus populations to avoid future spillover 396 events. Our study provides an example to assess the risk of a potential spillover from 397 viruses circulating in animal populations through the positive selection analysis, 398 structural modeling, and experimental verification.399 ACE2, a multifunctional enzyme involved in the negative regulation of the 400 renin-angiotensin system, also interacts with amino acid transporters and integrins (54, 401 23 55). ACE2 functions as a carboxypeptidase and its role as the SARS-CoV receptor 402 does not affect its peptidase activity. Moreover, the structural complex shows that the 403 SARS-CoV spike RBD does not block the catalytically-active site of ACE2 (21, 56). 404 Considering the conserved recognition site in receptor of SARSr-CoV clade 1, the 405 interface of SARS-CoV and ACE2 interaction would be an ideal target for drug 406 screening against a broad range of infections caused by these viruses. samples, cells, and viruses 414 Bat samples were from the biobank of our laboratory. Vero E6, HeLa, and HEK 415 293T/17 cells (ATCC) were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium 416 (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS). Cells were cultured at 417 37°C with 5% CO2. Bat SARSr-CoV-RsWIV1 and recombinant viruses with RsWIV1 418 as the backbone and replaced by different spike genes of bat SARSr-CoVs (RsWIV16, 419RsSHC014, and Rs4231) were cultured as previously described(16, 57). Titers of all 420 viruses used in this study were determined by plaque assays on Vero E6 cells, as 421 previously described (17).

FIGREF20.text: Amplification, cloning, and expression of bats ACE2 gene424 24 Bat ACE2 gene was amplified using DNA from the intestinal tissue of bats. In brief, 425 total RNA was extracted from bat intestine tissue using the RNAprep pure Kit (for 426 Cell/Bacteria) (TIANGEN, Beijing, China). First-strand complementary DNA was 427 synthesized from total RNA by reverse transcription with random hexamers; 428 full-length bat ACE2 fragments were amplified by reverse-transcription nested 429 polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Primers were designed based on available 430 ACE2 sequences from NCBI. First-round primers are as follows: ACE2-in-TTCTAAAABGAVGTYTGAAC. The ACE2 gene was cloned into the 435 pcDNA3.1 vector with XhoI and BamHI. N-terminal mouse Igk or human IFNα1 436 signal peptide and S-tag were inserted. The plasmids were verified by sequencing. 437 The expression of human and R. sinicus ACE2 was confirmed by western blotting and 438 immunofluorescence assay. 439 440 Expression constructs, protein expression, and purification 441 The constructs used for protein expression and purification were individually prepared 442 by inserting coding sequences for SARS-CoV-BJ01 RBD (spike residues: aa 317-569， 443 accession number: AY278488.2 ), RsWIV1 RBD (spike residues: aa 318-570， 444 accession number: KF367457.1), RsSHC014 RBD (spike residues: aa 318-570, 445 accession number: KC881005.1), R. sinicus ACE2 (aa 19-615, accession numbers are 446 25 listed in

FIGREF21.text: trees were built by the maximum likelihood method implemented in RAxML program 541 in CIPRES Science Gateway (https://www.phylo.org/). Maximum likelihood analysis 542 of dN/dS was performed using the codeml program in the PAML4.7 software package, 543 as previously described (31, 39). In brief, multiple alignments were fit to NSsites 544 models M1a, M2a, M7, M8a, and M8. Model fitting was performed with multiple 545 seed values for dN/dS and assuming either the F61 or F3x4 model of codon 546 frequencies. We used likelihood ratio tests (LRTs) to assess a better fit of codons that 547 allowed positive selection. Posterior probabilities of codons under positive selection 548 in different models were inferred using the Bayes empirical Bayes (BEB) algorithm. complete ACE2 sequences of R. sinicus and R. affinis ACE2 obtained in this 552 study have been deposited in the GenBank database and the accession numbers are 553 listed in

TABREF0.text: . Although the K31T change would fail to form a salt bridge with Glu35, Tyr442 in BJ01 RBD can form a hydrogen bond with it (29).However, a serine at 442 in RsWIV1 RBD cannot. Besides, RsSHC014 contains an 250 arginine at 479, and Thr31 cannot form a salt bridge with Glu35, making Glu35 available to form a salt bridge with Arg479, but the RBD residue Asn479 in RsWIV1 may lose this ability. Consequently, BJ01 and RsSHC014 RBD can bind with R. sinicus ACE2-1434, but not RsWIV1.

TABREF4.text: medium was added back at each time point. Viral RNA was extracted from the supernatant using the Viral RNA Mini Kit (Qiagen, Waltham, MA, USA) and then quantified on the ABI Step One system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA), with the AgPath-ID One-Step RT-PCR Kit (Applied Biosystems life technologies, Waltham, MA, USA). RNA dilutions from purifiedSARSr-CoV-RsWIV1 stock were used as a standard (with a titer of 6.5 × 10 6 PFU/mL). Every sample was analyzed in triplicate on two independent occasions.Binding assays between SARS/SARSr-CoV RBD and human or R. sinicus ACE2 protein were performed using the Octet RED system (ForteBio, Menlo Park, CA, USA) in 96-well microplates at 30°C, as described previously (59, 60). Briefly, the RBD was biotinylated using EZ-Link NHS-LC-LC-Biotin (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The assay was carried out by placing the Streptavidin Biosensors (ForteBio, Menlo Park, CA, USA) in the wells and measuring changes in layer thickness (nm) over time (s). First, the sensors were rinsed in the kinetic buffer497(1 M NaCl, 0.1% BSA, 0.02% Tween-20; pH 6.5) for 120 s, which served as the baseline. Thereafter, the sensors were immobilized for 600 s, with 200 μL buffer containing biotinylated SARSr-CoV RBD (50 μg/mL). Subsequently, the sensors were washed in the kinetic buffer for 200 s. Finally, the sensors were exposed to a series of diluted ACE2 protein run in 200 μL volumes. The association between each RBD and its corresponding ACE2 binding partner was monitored for 900 s. This was followed by monitoring their dissociation in the kinetic buffer for 900 s. During the entire experiment, the sample plate was kept shaking at 1000 rpm, and an RBD-loaded biosensor was used in association with the buffer as a baseline. Data analysis from the ForteBio Octet RED instrument includes reference subtraction.Inter-step correction and Y-alignment were used to minimize tip-dependent variability.Data were globally fitted in a 1:1 model using the Data Analysis Software v7.1 (ForteBio, Menlo Park, CA, USA).Pseudotyped production and infection of ACE2-transfected HeLa cellsSARS-CoV-BJ01 pseudotyped particles were produced by HEK 293T/17 cells. Plasmids, pcDNA3.1-BJ01-S and pNL4-3.luc.R-E-, were co-transfected into HEK 293T/17 cells. At 6 h post-transfection, the medium was replaced with fresh 293T FreeStyle expression medium. The supernatant, which contained the pseudotyped particles, was harvested 48 h post-transfection and filtered using 0.45 μm filters. Thereafter, the pseudotyped particles were aliquoted and stored at -80°C until further use. The viral titer was determined by the HIV p24 Quantitation ELISA Kits (Kyab Biotech Co. Ltd., Wuhan, China) before the viruses were used for the infection assay. HeLa cells were transfected with the same amount of human or R. sinicus ACE2 plasmids. After 24 h, the cells were incubated with SARS-CoV-BJ01 pseudotyped at an MOI = 1 or 0.1 for 1 h at 37°C, washed twice with D-Hanks solution, and supplemented with DMEM containing 10% FBS. Luciferase activity was determined using a GloMax luminometer (Promega Biotech Co. Ltd., Beijing, China) 48 h after infection. Each sample was analyzed in triplicate on two independent occasions.The structure complex of SARS-CoV/SARSr-CoVs RBD and R. sinicus ACE2 was homology modeled using SWISS-MODEL (https://swissmodel.expasy.org/), based on the structure of human SARS-CoV RBD (hTor2 RBD) complexed with human ACE2 (hACE2) and civet-optimized RBD complexed with hACE2 (Protein Data Bank ID: 2AJF, 3SCJ) (29). Molecular graphics visualization and analyses were performed using the UCSF Chimera software (http://www.rbvi.ucsf.edu/chimera).
